Article.ArticleTitle: Enhancing hydroxyl radical production from cathodic ozone reduction during the ozone-electrolysis process with flow-through reactive electrochemical membrane cathode.

AbstractText: In this study, a flow-through ozone-electrolysis (O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis) process was developed by combining ozonation with an electrolysis using a porous reactive electrochemical membrane (REM) cathode. Due to the convection-enhanced mass transport and fast radial diffusion inside the small pores of REM cathodes, the rate of cathodic O<sub>3</sub> reduction to ozonide radicals (O<sub>3</sub><sup>•-</sup>) was significantly enhanced, while the further cathodic O<sub>3</sub><sup>•-</sup> reduction to oxygen was inhibited during the flow-through O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process compared to the conventional mixed-tank O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process. Consequently, more hydroxyl radicals (•OH) were formed from O<sub>3</sub><sup>•-</sup> decay in water during the flow-through O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process than the mixed-tank O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process. Corresponding to the higher •OH yields from cathodic O<sub>3</sub> reduction, the flow-through O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process substantially enhanced the abatement kinetics and efficiency of para-benzoic acid (pCBA, a model compound of ozone-resistant micropollutant) in a groundwater than conventional ozonation and the mixed-tank O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process. These results suggest that the flow-through O<sub>3</sub>-electrolysis process may provide a competitive treatment technology for micropollutant abatement in water treatment.
